conclusion: To find the radius r_max of a drop just before it separates from the nozzle, we need to balance the forces acting on the droplet.
The droplet separates when the gravitational force F_g overcomes the surface tension force F_0.
The gravitational force acting on the droplet is given by F_g = (4/3) π r^3 ρ g.
ρ is the density of water and g is the acceleration due to gravity.
The surface tension force is given by F_0 = σ · circumference of the neck.
The circumference of the neck (where the drop separates) is approximately 2π d, with d being the diameter of the pipe.
At the point of separation, the gravitational force equals the surface tension force: (4/3) π r^3 ρ g = σ · 2π d.
Simplify the equation: (4/3) r^3 ρ g = σ · 2 d.
Isolate r^3: r^3 = (3 σ d) / (2 ρ g).
Take the cube root: r = ((3 σ d) / (2 ρ g))^(1/3).
The maximum radius r_max of the drop just before it separates from the nozzle is r_max = ((3 σ d) / (2 ρ g))^(1/3).
This expression gives the critical radius as a function of the surface tension, diameter of the pipe, density of the water, and gravitational acceleration.
